questions.question: They knelt in front of the child who ............................ one day rule their country.
questions.description: The main verb is in the past tense, so we need an auxiliary referring to the past time in the dependent clause.

questions.question: How many people ...................... get into a telephone booth?
questions.description: We use 'can' to talk about theoretical possibility.

questions.question: I .............................. not do this if I did not have to.
questions.description: If the verb in the if-clause is in the simple past tense, we use 'would + infinitive' in the main clause.

questions.question: If you stopped talking, I ......................... get some work done.
................................. a visa for Malaysia?
questions.description: The auxiliary need is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: Let's go for a walk, ............................ we?
questions.description: After 'let's' we use 'shall we' in question tags.

questions.question: You ............................... work on Sundays.
questions.description: Need can be used as an auxiliary verb and as a regular verb. When need is an auxiliary, it is followed by an infinitive without to. When need is used as a regular verb, it is followed by an infinitive with to and questions and negatives are made with do.

questions.question: She really ........................... to mend her ways.
questions.description: Ought is followed by an infinitive with to.

questions.question: She ............................. speak six languages.
questions.description: We use can to show ability may indicates possibility.

questions.question: Life ............................... be more interesting when I was a child.
questions.description: Would cannot be used to talk about habitual states in the past. Only used to is possible with that meaning.

questions.question: Granny ....................... always bring us nice gifts.
questions.description: Both 'would' and 'used to' can be used to talk about past habits.
